perturbation.original_text: Term and Termination. This Agreement and the license granted herein shall remain effective until terminated. Customer may terminate this Agreement and the license at any time by destroying all copies of Software including any Documentation. Customer's rights under this Agreement will terminate immediately without notice from Cisco if Customer fails to comply with any provision of this Agreement. Upon termination, Customer shall destroy all copies of Software and Documentation in its possession or control.
perturbation.changed_text: Term and Termination. This Agreement and the license granted herein shall remain effective until terminated. Customer may terminate this Agreement and the license at any time by destroying all copies of Software including any Documentation. Customer's rights under this Agreement will terminate if Customer fails to comply with any provision of this Agreement; however, Cisco will provide a 30-day written notice before termination due to non-compliance, giving the Customer time to rectify the breach. Upon termination, Customer shall destroy all copies of Software and Documentation in its possession or control.
perturbation.explanation: The modification introduces a contradiction regarding the termination process. The original clause states immediate termination without notice for non-compliance, while the modified version adds a 30-day notice period. This creates ambiguity and potential legal challenges in enforcing the termination clause, particularly under contract law principles of reasonable notice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles related to termination and reasonable notice.

perturbation.changed_text: Disclaimer of Liabilities. IN NO EVENT WILL CISCO OR ITS SUPPLIERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY LOST REVENUE, PROFIT, OR LOST OR DAMAGED DATA, OR FOR SPECIAL, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL, INCIDENTAL, OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES HOWEVER CAUSED AND REGARDLESS OF THE THEORY OF LIABILITY OR WHETHER ARISING OUT OF THE USE OF OR INABILITY TO USE SOFTWARE OR OTHERWISE AND EVEN IF CISCO OR ITS SUPPLIERS OR LICENSORS HAVE BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES. In no event shall Cisco's or its suppliers' or licensors' liability to Customer, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), or otherwise, exceed the price paid by Customer for the Software that gave rise to the claim or if the Software is part of another Product, the price paid for such other Product, unless gross negligence or willful misconduct on the part of Cisco is proven. The foregoing limitations shall apply even if the above​ stated warranty fails of its essential purpose. BECAUSE SOME STATES OR JURISDICTIONS DO NOT ALLOW LIMITATION OR EXCLUSION OF CONSEQUENTIAL OR INCIDENTAL DAMAGES, THE ABOVE LIMITATION MAY NOT APPLY TO YOU.
perturbation.explanation: The addition of 'unless gross negligence or willful misconduct on the part of Cisco is proven' introduces an exception to the liability limitation. While some jurisdictions may disallow limitations on liability for gross negligence, its inclusion here creates internal inconsistency. The initial clause disclaims liability for all damages, but the added phrase suggests liability could exist under specific circumstances. This weakens the disclaimer and introduces legal uncertainty.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law and limitations of liability clauses, particularly concerning gross negligence or willful misconduct.

perturbation.original_text:
License. Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Cisco Systems, Inc. or its subsidiary licensing the Software instead of Cisco Systems, Inc. ("Cisco"), grants to Customer a nonexclusive and nontransferable license to use for Customer's internal business purposes the Software and the Documentation for which Customer has paid the required license fees. "Documentation" means written information (whether contained in user or technical manuals, training materials, specifications or otherwise) regarding the Software and made available by Cisco in any manner (including on CD-Rom, or on-line).

Customer's license to use the Software shall be limited to, and Customer shall not use the Software in excess of, a single hardware chassis or card or that number of agent(s), concurrent users, sessions, IP addresses, port(s), seat(s), server(s) or site(s), as set forth in the applicable Purchase Order which has been accepted by Cisco and for which Customer has paid to Cisco the required license fee.
perturbation.changed_text:
License. Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Cisco Systems, Inc. or its subsidiary licensing the Software instead of Cisco Systems, Inc. ("Cisco"), grants to Customer a nonexclusive license to use for Customer's internal business purposes the Software and the Documentation regardless of whether required license fees have been paid. "Documentation" means written information (whether contained in user or technical manuals, training materials, specifications or otherwise) regarding the Software and made available by Cisco in any manner (including on CD-Rom, or on-line).

Customer's license to use the Software shall be limited to, and Customer shall not use the Software in excess of, a single hardware chassis or card or that number of agent(s), concurrent users, sessions, IP addresses, port(s), seat(s), server(s) or site(s), as set forth in the applicable Purchase Order which has been accepted by Cisco and for which Customer has paid to Cisco the required license fee. Customer will be granted a perpetual license once the first payment has been made.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates an internal contradiction. Initially, the license is granted 'for which Customer has paid the required license fees'. However, the addition of 'regardless of whether required license fees have been paid' directly contradicts this. Furthermore, the grant of a perpetual license after the first payment contradicts the entire licensing structure. It becomes unclear whether payment is a prerequisite for the license, making the clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract in a payment agreement.
